content: Modern supply chain management utilizes network analysis techniques to optimize the flow of goods from manufacturers to consumers.
Network optimization helps companies reduce costs, improve delivery times, and enhance overall supply chain resilience.
Supply chain networks are modeled as complex adaptive systems where nodes represent facilities and edges represent transportation links or business relationships.
Hub-and-spoke configurations enable economies of scale but create potential single points of failure.
Direct shipping networks provide greater flexibility and resilience but result in higher per-unit transportation costs.
Disruptions at tier-two suppliers can propagate forward through multi-tier networks, affecting multiple downstream manufacturers.
Network mapping allows for proactive risk management and the development of contingency plans by identifying dependency relationships.
Supply chain network optimization involves balancing cost minimization with service level maximization.
